docs.lead_paragraph: Q. I bought a long-term care insurance policy in the 1980's, when you could only get nursing home coverage. Can I switch to a policy that also covers home care? A. For many people in good health, it is not only possible but strongly recommended. The reasons are several: People are living longer and relying more on home care while the Government is threatening to cut back on such aid. So if you are over age 50 with a net worth of at least $250,000, it is time to start shopping around for a policy that includes home care. If you are worth less, the annual cost of additional coverage could be an overwhelming burden.

headline.main: Why, and When, Home Care Insurance Is Needed

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH THE GOVERNMENT STILL CLOSED after 21 days, the Speaker was ready to speak. "Hobson!" he bellowed. "Either sit down and shut up or leave the room!" Normally at a caucus of the 236 House Republicans official business competes with a buzz of background conversation. But on this morning in early January, as he stood in the high-ceilinged caucus room of the Cannon Building, across from the Capitol, Newt Gingrich wanted quiet. He had said so once, politely. Now he had a 59-year-old Congressman, David L. Hobson, hurrying to his seat. "I won't be taking questions," Gingrich continued, addressing the suddenly silent room. He had heard plenty the previous day, when he first told other House Republicans of his plan to reopen the Government. With his party bearing the brunt of the public's pique, Gingrich wanted services restored, at least partly, until the middle of March. But the caucus was on the verge of rebellion.

headline.main: Rant, Listen, Exploit, Learn, Scare, Help, Manipulate, Lead

docs.lead_paragraph: JUST a relatively short time ago, the Western medical community looked askance at so-called Eastern therapies like acupuncture. Today, in contrast, the practice of using tiny needles to cure certain ailments is given a great deal of acceptance in the United States -- so much so that the New York Medical College recently began a training program in acupuncture for doctors and dentists. Heading the new certificate training program is Dr. Ravinder Mamtani, a professor of clinical, preventive and community medicine. Dr. Mamtani was born in India, where he attended medical school. He did his postgraduate training in internal medicine and community medicine in England.

headline.main: Westchester Q&A: Dr. Ravinder Mamtani;Gaining Acceptance for Acupuncture

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE day last fall, Oct. 19 to be exact, started out as just another busy time for Victoria Miller, wife, mother of five and parish secretary at Our Lady of the Lakes Roman Catholic Church in New Milford. She was at work at about 1 P.M. when she first began to feel odd. Ten minutes later, Mrs. Miller had a seizure and collapsed. She was rushed by ambulance to New Milford Hospital where a CAT scan and an M.R.I. showed a brain tumor. Dr. Joan Puglia, a neurologist, recommended that Mrs. Miller "go to a hospital where something like this is ordinary," Mrs. Miller recalled. Dr. Puglia gave her patient three choices: Yale-New Haven Hospital, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York or Memorial Sloan-Kettering, also in New York. Yale-New Haven and Columbia-Presbyterian, each a 75-minute drive, were the closest. Dr. Puglia recommended Columbia-Presbyterian because she was pleased with earlier referrals to a neurosurgeon there. "That's how we decided where to go," Mrs. Miller said.

headline.main: A Hospital Winds Up With an Out of State Partner

docs.lead_paragraph: After shrouding his pharmacy in black crepe one morning last fall, Joseph Tarallo parked a borrowed hearse out front and grabbed a microphone. As a small crowd gathered, he railed against the drug and insurance companies that he says are quashing his business. "We had to call attention to our problems," he said last week, recalling his day of protest. "We had to let our customers know we won't be here much longer if things don't change."

headline.main: Small Pharmacies Squeezed by the Health Care Revolution

docs.lead_paragraph: THE first residents are arriving at a new retirement community in this village just north of Ithaca, giving New York State its first glimpse of a living option popular with older people in many other states -- the continuing care retirement community. But not surprisingly for a state that long banned facilities that collect payments on the promise of future medical care, it has some special New York twists, and a New York name -- the life-care retirement community. The developer had to navigate a rigorous regulatory review, intended to assure fiscal soundness.

docs.lead_paragraph: After two years of cutting taxes while increasing state spending, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will chart a different course in her third state budget, by reducing overall spending, if only slightly, through cuts in almost every state agency. The Governor's $15.98 billion spending plan, outlined today by senior administration officials, is $124 million lower than the budget for the current fiscal year, which ends June 30. That amounts to a spending decrease of less than 1 percent.

headline.main: WHITMAN'S BUDGET CALLS FOR A DROP IN STATE SPENDING

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN 1995 started, Carlos Torres had a $22,000-a-year job as a supervisor at an auto parts factory in Essex County. When it ended, he was a charity patient at St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center here, still a little dazed by his run of bad luck. First the plant closed. Then his unemployment insurance ran out. Then last fall, just after he'd finally lined up a new job, he fell on a street in Paterson and shattered his right arm. It still hasn't healed properly.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two years ago President Clinton challenged Congress to pass a bill that would overhaul the entire health-care industry. In this week's State of the Union address, he settled for a much diminished, yet welcome, goal. The President called on Congress to pass a bipartisan bill, sponsored by Senators Kassebaum and Kennedy, that would make it easier for individuals with health problems to buy coverage. The bill was approved unanimously in committee in August but has been inexplicably denied a floor vote by the majority leader, Bob Dole, who two years ago sponsored a bill that included nearly the same provisions. The Kassebaum-Kennedy bill would not guarantee every American health insurance. Nor would it fix most of the other maladies of the health-care industry. But it would help millions of workers who lose their employer-based coverage and are then turned away by other insurers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Sharpe James said today that he had reassigned his longtime chief of staff, indicted this week on charges of accepting bribes in exchange for city contracts, to a new, unspecified job in the Department of Health and Human Services. The announcement came in a short statement noting that the Mayor "was saddened" by the indictment of Jackie R. Mattison, who in addition to being a close friend and confidant of the Mayor is also an Assemblyman. Mr. James did not make himself available to describe Mr. Mattison's new job or answer questions on whether a new chief of staff would be named. A spokeswoman at the Health Department said she was unaware that Mr. Mattison was joining the department.

headline.main: Indicted Aide Is Reassigned In Newark
